title: 01_introduction
text:
What is mathematical optimization?
We have a complex decision problem to solve.

Running a business: maximize profit, minimize loss, maximize efficiency, or minimize risk.
Design: minimize the weight of a bridge/truss and maximize the strength within the design constraints.
Planning: select a flight route to minimize time or fuel consumption of an airplane.








Philosophy


Approach the problem, involving the selection of values for a number of interrelated variables, by focusing attention on a single objective designed to quantify performance and measure the quality of the decision.









Important


This one objective is maximized subject to the constraints that may limit the selection of decision variable values.

title: 01_introduction
text:
Problem formulation
 

Always involves a tradeoff between conflicting objectives:

building a mathematical model suffiently complex to accurately capture the problem description,
building a model that is tractable.

The expert model builder is facile with both aspects of this tradeoff.
One aspiring to become such an expert must learn to identify and capture the important issues of a problem mainly through example and experience.
One must learn to distinguish tractable models from nontractable ones

study of available theory
nurturing the capability to extend existing theory to new situations.

title: 01_introduction
text:
Linear Programming



Linear programming (LP) is the most natural mechanism for formulating a vast array of problems with modest effort.
LPs are characterized by linear functions of the unknowns:

objective is linear in the unknowns,
constraints are linear (in)equalities in the unknowns.

LP formulations are popular because

mathematics is nicer,
the theory is richer,
the computation is simpler.




Consider a budget problem:

Total amount of money is to be allocated among two different commodities: x1+x2≤B 
x_1 + x_2 \leq B

Objective is to maximize the weight: w1x1+w2x2
w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2
 where wj,j=1,2w_j, \, j=1,2 is the unit weight of commodity jj.

title: 01_introduction
text:
Good-old days


 


18th18^{th} century Europe was fascinated by automata such as Vaucanson’s duck, which was complex by the standards of the day.



Jacquard extended these ideas and developed a loom, which was essentially a programmable weaving machine.

title: 01_introduction
text:
Good-old days

The term robot was first introduced by the Czech playwright Karel Čapek in his 19201920 play Rossum’s Universal Robots.
The word robota is the Czech word for worker.





The first patent for what we would now consider a robot was filed in 19541954 by George C. Devol.
The device comprised a mechanical arm with a gripper that was mounted on a track.

title: 01_introduction
text:
Let’s get started!





Robots are still far behind what many people expect them to be from movies.



One thing is certain: robotics will be an important technology in this century.

Vacuum cleaning robots have already been with us for over a decade.
Self driving cars are coming.
